abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Development Project
            seeks to improve the management of water resources and
            increase the quality, reliability and coverage of urban and
            rural water supply services, in support of the
            implementation of the National Water Policy. The project has
            three components: i) urban and peri-urban water supply; ii)
            rural water and sanitation; and iii) water resources
            management. This project will involve little resettlements.
            However, the study does provide guidance for future
            resettlement planning, as well as standard environmental
            requirements. During construction, noise, dust and air
            emissions should be minimized by using modern equipment.
            Measures must be taken to prevent oils and chemicals from
            seeping into the ground or into water courses. Used oils and
            lubricants should be collected and disposed out of the
            working area. Trenches should be carefully backfilled to
            avoid later subsidence and erosion. During operation, intake
            water quality should be monitored regularly to minimize the
            risk of unknown substance or minerals adversely affecting
            drinking water. Significant leakage of pipes will cause
            erosion and flooding, and should be prevented by automatic
            monitoring of pressure of flow.
